title: 109_hr6420
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tax Exempt Hospitals Responsibility Act of 2006" and specifies required policies and procedures for certain medical care providers. The "Tax Exempt Hospitals Responsibility Act of 2006" amends Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code to require specified medical care providers to have policies and procedures for providing necessary care to low-income uninsured individuals. No deduction is allowed for providers who do not comply with these requirements. The amendments made by the "Tax Exempt Hospitals Responsibility Act of 2006" apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007, under various sections of the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 3. Failure by specified medical care provider to meet minimum charity care requirement. Amends Chapter 42 of the Internal Revenue Code to add a new subchapter regarding failure to meet charity care requirements by specified medical care providers. Sec. 4968 imposes a $1,000 tax on a specified medical care provider for failing to provide specified medically necessary care to a low-income uninsured individual during an in-person visit. "Sec. 4968A imposes an excise tax on a specified medical care provider for overcharging for specified medically necessary care." Imposition of Tax: A tax is imposed on a specified medical care provider if they charge a low-income uninsured individual more than the maximum allowed charges for necessary care. The maximum allowed charges are $25 per visit for individuals with an annual household income up to 100% of the poverty line, and the average amount paid for those with incomes between 100% and 200% of the poverty line. The tax is imposed on a specified medical care provider based on the average amount paid for necessary care under contracts with private health insurers. The excise tax is imposed on a specified medical care provider for failure to disclose charitable medical care information and negotiated charges. If a specified medical care provider fails to disclose charitable medical care information and negotiated charges, a tax of $1,000 is imposed for each failure. The provider must disclose policies on providing and charging for necessary care to patients during admission and when billing for services. The specified medical care provider must disclose policies on providing and charging for necessary care, as well as average prices paid for each procedure. A maximum tax of $50,000 is imposed for each failure to disclose this information. "SEC. 4968C. DEFINITIONS." The term 'specified medical care provider' under this subchapter refers to organizations described in section 501(c)(3) providing medical or hospital care, medical education, or research actively engaged in medical care, or required to be licensed as a hospital under State law. Exclusions include convalescent homes, homes for children, or the aged. The term 'specified medically necessary care' refers to medical care provided by specified medical care providers, excluding care deemed unnecessary by the treating physician or waived by the low-income uninsured individual. The term 'specified medically necessary care' includes organ transplants, cosmetic or experimental treatments, and care to improve the functioning of a malformed body part. A 'low-income uninsured individual' is someone without medical insurance, with an annual household income not exceeding 200 percent of the poverty line. A 'low-income uninsured individual' must meet certain criteria, including citizenship or residency in the US, not being eligible for government-sponsored insurance, and complying with requests for documentation. The term 'poverty line' is defined as the threshold for annual household income. The term 'poverty line' is defined in section 673 of the Community Services Block Grant Act. A new subchapter is added for failure by specified medical care providers to meet minimum charity care requirements. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
